entry.title: YC是怎样开始的
entry.content:
How Y Combinator Started

YC是怎样开始的

原文链接: https://paulgraham.com/ycstart.html

March 2012

Y Combinator’s 7th birthday was March 11. As usual we were so busy we didn’t notice till a few days after. I don’t think we’ve ever managed to remember our birthday on our birthday.

Y Combinator的7岁生日是3月11日。和往常一样，我们太忙了，直到几天后才想起来。我想我们从来没有在生日当天记得过自己的生日。

On March 11 2005, Jessica and I were walking home from dinner in Harvard Square. Jessica was working at an investment bank at the time, but she didn’t like it much, so she had interviewed for a job as director of marketing at a Boston VC fund. The VC fund was doing what now seems a comically familiar thing for a VC fund to do: taking a long time to make up their mind. Meanwhile I had been telling Jessica all the things they should change about the VC business — essentially the ideas now underlying Y Combinator: investors should be making more, smaller investments, they should be funding hackers instead of suits, they should be willing to fund younger founders, etc.
2005年3月11日，Jessica和我从哈佛广场吃完晚餐步行回家。当时Jessica在一家投资银行工作，但她不太喜欢那份工作，所以她面试了波士顿一家风险投资基金的营销总监职位。这家风投基金正在做一件现在看来颇具讽刺意味的熟悉事情：迟迟不做决定。同时，我一直在告诉Jessica风投行业应该改变的所有事情——基本上就是现在构成Y Combinator基础的理念：投资者应该做更多、更小的投资，他们应该资助黑客而不是西装革履的商人，他们应该愿意资助更年轻的创始人等等。

At the time I had been thinking about doing some angel investing. I had just given a talk to the undergraduate computer club at Harvard about how to start a startup, and it hit me afterward that although I had always meant to do angel investing, 7 years had now passed since I got enough money to do it, and I still hadn’t started. I had also been thinking about ways to work with Robert Morris and Trevor Blackwell again. A few hours before I had sent them an email trying to figure out what we could do together.
那时我一直在考虑做一些天使投资。我刚在哈佛大学本科生计算机俱乐部做了一个关于如何创业的演讲，之后我突然意识到，尽管我一直打算做天使投资，但自从我有足够资金做这件事已经过去了7年，而我仍然没有开始。我也一直在思考如何再次与Robert Morris和Trevor Blackwell合作。几小时前，我给他们发了一封电子邮件，试图找出我们可以一起做的事情。

Between Harvard Square and my house the idea gelled. We’d start our own investment firm and Jessica could work for that instead. As we turned onto Walker Street we decided to do it. I agreed to put 100kintothenewfundandJessicaagreedtoquitherjobtoworkforit.OverthenextcoupledaysIrecruitedRobertandTrevor,whoputinanother50k each. So YC started with $200k.
从哈佛广场到我家的路上，这个想法逐渐成形。我们要创办自己的投资公司，Jessica可以在那里工作。当我们拐到Walker Street时，我们决定就这么做。我同意向新基金投入10万美元，Jessica同意辞去工作加入。在接下来的几天里，我招募了Robert和Trevor，他们每人又投入了5万美元。所以YC以20万美元起步。

Jessica was so happy to be able to quit her job and start her own company that I took her picture when we got home.
Jessica能够辞去工作开始自己的公司是如此开心，以至于我们到家时我给她拍了张照片。

The company wasn’t called Y Combinator yet. At first we called it Cambridge Seed. But that name never saw the light of day, because by the time we announced it a few days later, we’d changed the name to Y Combinator. We realized early on that what we were doing could be national in scope and we didn’t want a name that tied us to one place.
公司当时还不叫Y Combinator。起初我们称它为Cambridge Seed。但这个名字从未见光，因为当我们几天后宣布时，我们已经将名字改为了Y Combinator。我们很早就意识到我们所做的工作可能会在全国范围内展开，我们不想要一个将我们限制在一个地方的名称。

Initially we only had part of the idea. We were going to do seed funding with standardized terms. Before YC, seed funding was very haphazard. You’d get that first $10k from your friend’s rich uncle. The deal terms were often a disaster; often neither the investor nor the founders nor the lawyer knew what the documents should look like. Facebook’s early history as a Florida LLC shows how random things could be in those days. We were going to be something there had not been before: a standard source of seed funding.
最初我们只有部分想法。我们打算用标准化条款进行种子投资。在YC之前，种子投资非常随意。你会从你朋友富有的叔叔那里获得第一笔1万美元。交易条款往往是灾难性的；通常投资者、创始人和律师都不知道文件应该是什么样子。Facebook早期作为佛罗里达州有限责任公司的历史展示了那个时代事情可以多么随意。我们打算成为前所未有的东西：一个标准化的种子资金来源。

We modelled YC on the seed funding we ourselves had taken when we started Viaweb. We started Viaweb with 10kwegotfromourfriendJulianWeber,thehusbandofIdelleWeber,whosepaintingclassItookasagradstudentatHarvard.Julianknewaboutbusiness,butyouwouldnotdescribehimasasuit.Amongotherthingshe
′
dbeenpresidentoftheNationalLampoon.Hewasalsoalawyer,andgotallourpaperworksetupproperly.Inreturnfor10k, getting us set up as a company, teaching us what business was about, and remaining calm in times of crisis, Julian got 10% of Viaweb. I remember thinking once what a good deal Julian got. And then a second later I realized that without Julian, Viaweb would never have made it. So even though it was a good deal for him, it was a good deal for us too. That’s why I knew there was room for something like Y Combinator.
我们以自己创办Viaweb时获得的种子资金为模型创建了YC。我们用从朋友Julian Weber那里获得的1万美元创办了Viaweb，Julian是Idelle Weber的丈夫，我在哈佛读研究生时上过Idelle的绘画课。Julian懂商业，但你不会把他描述为一个西装革履的商人。他曾担任《国家讽刺》杂志的总裁。他也是一名律师，帮我们妥善处理了所有文件。作为1万美元、帮我们成立公司、教我们商业知识以及在危机时刻保持冷静的回报，Julian获得了Viaweb 10%的股份。我记得有一次我想Julian得到了多好的交易。但一秒钟后我意识到，没有Julian，Viaweb永远不会成功。所以尽管这对他来说是个好交易，对我们来说也是个好交易。这就是为什么我知道像Y Combinator这样的东西有存在空间。

Initially we didn’t have what turned out to be the most important idea: funding startups synchronously, instead of asynchronously as it had always been done before. Or rather we had the idea, but we didn’t realize its significance. We decided very early that the first thing we’d do would be to fund a bunch of startups over the coming summer. But we didn’t realize initially that this would be the way we’d do all our investing. The reason we began by funding a bunch of startups at once was not that we thought it would be a better way to fund startups, but simply because we wanted to learn how to be angel investors, and a summer program for undergrads seemed the fastest way to do it. No one takes summer jobs that seriously. The opportunity cost for a bunch of undergrads to spend a summer working on startups was low enough that we wouldn’t feel guilty encouraging them to do it.
最初我们没有后来证明是最重要的想法：同步资助初创公司，而不是像以前那样异步进行。或者更准确地说，我们有这个想法，但我们没有意识到它的重要性。我们很早就决定，我们要做的第一件事就是在即将到来的夏天资助一批初创公司。但最初我们没有意识到这将成为我们所有投资的方式。我们开始一次性资助一批初创公司的原因并不是因为我们认为这是资助初创公司更好的方式，而是因为我们想学习如何成为天使投资者，而针对本科生的暑期项目似乎是最快的方法。没有人会非常认真地对待暑期工作。一群本科生花一个夏天在初创公司工作的机会成本足够低，我们不会因为鼓励他们这样做而感到内疚。

We knew students would already be making plans for the summer, so we did what we’re always telling startups to do: we launched fast. Here are the initial announcement and description of what was at the time called the Summer Founders Program.
我们知道学生已经开始为夏天做计划，所以我们做了我们一直告诉初创公司要做的事情：快速启动。以下是当时被称为”夏季创始人计划”的初始公告和描述。

We got lucky in that the length and structure of a summer program turns out to be perfect for what we do. The structure of the YC cycle is still almost identical to what it was that first summer.
我们很幸运，暑期项目的长度和结构恰好完美适合我们的工作。YC周期的结构至今几乎与那个第一个夏天完全相同。

We also got lucky in who the first batch of founders were. We never expected to make any money from that first batch. We thought of the money we were investing as a combination of an educational expense and a charitable donation. But the founders in the first batch turned out to be surprisingly good. And great people too. We’re still friends with a lot of them today.
我们在第一批创始人的人选上也很幸运。我们从未期望从第一批人身上赚到钱。我们把投资的钱视为教育支出和慈善捐赠的结合。但第一批创始人出人意料地优秀。而且是很好的人。今天我们仍然与他们中的许多人保持友谊。

It’s hard for people to realize now how inconsequential YC seemed at the time. I can’t blame people who didn’t take us seriously, because we ourselves didn’t take that first summer program seriously in the very beginning. But as the summer progressed we were increasingly impressed by how well the startups were doing. Other people started to be impressed too. Jessica and I invented a term, “the Y Combinator effect,” to describe the moment when the realization hit someone that YC was not totally lame. When people came to YC to speak at the dinners that first summer, they came in the spirit of someone coming to address a Boy Scout troop. By the time they left the building they were all saying some variant of “Wow, these companies might actually succeed.”
现在人们很难意识到当时YC看起来多么微不足道。我不能责怪那些不认真对待我们的人，因为一开始我们自己也没有认真对待那个第一个暑期项目。但随着夏天的推移，初创公司的表现让我们越来越印象深刻。其他人也开始印象深刻。Jessica和我创造了一个术语，”Y Combinator效应”，用来描述当有人意识到YC并非完全无用时的那个时刻。当人们在第一个夏天来YC参加晚餐演讲时，他们带着像是来给童子军演讲的心态而来。当他们离开大楼时，他们都在说类似”哇，这些公司可能真的会成功”的话。

Now YC is well enough known that people are no longer surprised when the companies we fund are legit, but it took a while for reputation to catch up with reality. That’s one of the reasons we especially like funding ideas that might be dismissed as “toys” — because YC itself was dismissed as one initially.
现在YC已经足够出名，人们不再对我们资助的公司是合法的感到惊讶，但声誉跟上现实花了一段时间。这也是我们特别喜欢资助那些可能被视为”玩具”的想法的原因之一——因为YC本身最初也被视为一种玩具。

When we saw how well it worked to fund companies synchronously, we decided we’d keep doing that. We’d fund two batches of startups a year.
当我们看到同步资助公司效果如此之好时，我们决定继续这样做。我们每年将资助两批初创公司。

We funded the second batch in Silicon Valley. That was a last minute decision. In retrospect I think what pushed me over the edge was going to Foo Camp that fall. The density of startup people in the Bay Area was so much greater than in Boston, and the weather was so nice. I remembered that from living there in the 90s. Plus I didn’t want someone else to copy us and describe it as the Y Combinator of Silicon Valley. I wanted YC to be the Y Combinator of Silicon Valley. So doing the winter batch in California seemed like one of those rare cases where the self-indulgent choice and the ambitious one were the same.
我们在硅谷资助了第二批公司。那是一个临时决定。回想起来，我认为推动我做这个决定的是那年秋天去参加Foo Camp。湾区初创公司人员的密度远高于波士顿，而且天气很好。我90年代在那里生活时就记得这一点。另外，我不想让别人抄袭我们，称其为”硅谷的Y Combinator”。我想让YC成为”硅谷的Y Combinator”。所以在加州做冬季批次似乎是那种罕见的情况之一，自我放纵的选择和雄心勃勃的选择是相同的。

If we’d had enough time to do what we wanted, Y Combinator would have been in Berkeley. That was our favorite part of the Bay Area. But we didn’t have time to get a building in Berkeley. We didn’t have time to get our own building anywhere. The only way to get enough space in time was to convince Trevor to let us take over part of his (as it then seemed) giant building in Mountain View. Yet again we lucked out, because Mountain View turned out to be the ideal place to put something like YC. But even then we barely made it. The first dinner in California, we had to warn all the founders not to touch the walls, because the paint was still wet.
如果我们有足够的时间做我们想做的事，Y Combinator会在伯克利。那是我们最喜欢的湾区地区。但我们没有时间在伯克利找一栋建筑。我们没有时间在任何地方找到自己的建筑。唯一能及时获得足够空间的方法是说服Trevor让我们接管他在山景城的（当时看起来）巨大的建筑的一部分。我们又一次幸运了，因为山景城被证明是放置像YC这样的东西的理想地方。但即使如此，我们也勉强赶上了。在加州的第一次晚餐，我们必须警告所有创始人不要触摸墙壁，因为油漆还没干。

entry.title: 定义财产
entry.content:
Defining Property

定义财产

原文链接: https://paulgraham.com/property.html

March 2012

As a child I read a book of stories about a famous judge in eighteenth century Japan called Ooka Tadasuke. One of the cases he decided was brought by the owner of a food shop. A poor student who could afford only rice was eating his rice while enjoying the delicious cooking smells coming from the food shop. The owner wanted the student to pay for the smells he was enjoying.

小时候，我读过一本故事书，讲的是18世纪日本一位著名法官大冈忠相（Ooka Tadasuke）的事迹。他审理过这样一个案子：一家食品店的店主控告一名穷学生。这名学生只买得起米饭，却一边吃着米饭，一边享受从食品店里飘出的诱人饭菜香气。店主希望学生为他所享受的“气味”付费。

The student was stealing his smells!

这个学生是在偷他的气味！

This story often comes to mind when I hear the RIAA and MPAA accusing people of stealing music and movies.

每当我听到美国唱片业协会（RIAA）和美国电影协会（MPAA）指责人们“偷窃”音乐和电影时，这个故事就常常浮现在我脑海里。

It sounds ridiculous to us to treat smells as property. But I can imagine scenarios in which one could charge for smells. Imagine we were living on a moon base where we had to buy air by the liter. I could imagine air suppliers adding scents at an extra charge.

在我们看来，把气味当作财产是荒谬的。但我能想象一些可以对气味收费的情境。比如，假设我们住在一个月球基地上，必须按升购买空气。我可以想象空气供应商会额外收费添加香味。

The reason it seems ridiculous to us to treat smells as property is that it wouldn’t work to. It would work on a moon base, though.

之所以我们认为把气味当作财产很荒谬，是因为在现实中这样做行不通。但在月球基地上，这种做法却是可行的。

What counts as property depends on what works to treat as property. And that not only can change, but has changed. Humans may always (for some definition of human and always) have treated small items carried on one’s person as property. But hunter gatherers didn’t treat land, for example, as property in the way we do. [1]

什么被算作财产，取决于将其视为财产是否行得通。这不仅可能改变，而且已经发生过改变。人类或许始终（在某种对“人类”和“始终”的定义下）都将随身携带的小物件视为财产。但例如，狩猎采集者并不像我们今天这样将土地视为财产。[1]

The reason so many people think of property as having a single unchanging definition is that its definition changes very slowly. [2] But we are in the midst of such a change now. The record labels and movie studios used to distribute what they made like air shipped through tubes on a moon base. But with the arrival of networks, it’s as if we’ve moved to a planet with a breathable atmosphere. Data moves like smells now. And through a combination of wishful thinking and short-term greed, the labels and studios have put themselves in the position of the food shop owner, accusing us all of stealing their smells.

许多人认为财产具有单一且不变的定义，原因在于其定义变化非常缓慢。[2] 但我们正处在一个这样的变革之中。唱片公司和电影制片厂过去分发其作品的方式，就像在月球基地通过管道输送空气一样。但随着网络的出现，我们仿佛搬到了一个拥有可呼吸大气的星球上。如今，数据就像气味一样自由流动。而由于一厢情愿的幻想和短期贪婪，这些公司和制片厂把自己置于了那个食品店店主的位置，指控我们所有人“偷窃”他们的气味。

(The reason I say short-term greed is that the underlying problem with the labels and studios is that the people who run them are driven by bonuses rather than equity. If they were driven by equity they’d be looking for ways to take advantage of technological change instead of fighting it. But building new things takes too long. Their bonuses depend on this year’s revenues, and the best way to increase those is to extract more money from stuff they do already.)

（我之所以说这是“短期贪婪”，是因为唱片公司和制片厂的根本问题在于，其管理者受奖金而非股权驱动。如果他们受股权驱动，就会设法利用技术变革，而不是与之对抗。但构建新事物耗时太长。他们的奖金取决于本年度的收入，而提高收入的最佳方式就是从已有内容中榨取更多金钱。）

So what does this mean? Should people not be able to charge for content? There’s not a single yes or no answer to that question. People should be able to charge for content when it works to charge for content.

那么这意味着什么？人们就不该对内容收费了吗？这个问题没有简单的“是”或“否”的答案。只有在对内容收费行得通的情况下，人们才应该能够这么做。

But by “works” I mean something more subtle than “when they can get away with it.” I mean when people can charge for content without warping society in order to do it. After all, the companies selling smells on the moon base could continue to sell them on the Earth, if they lobbied successfully for laws requiring us all to continue to breathe through tubes down here too, even though we no longer needed to.

但我说的“行得通”，意思比“只要他们能侥幸成功”要更微妙。我的意思是，当人们可以在不扭曲社会的前提下对内容收费。毕竟，那些在月球基地卖气味的公司，如果成功游说立法强制我们在地球上也必须继续通过管道呼吸（即使我们已不再需要），他们就能继续在地球上卖气味。

The crazy legal measures that the labels and studios have been taking have a lot of that flavor. Newspapers and magazines are just as screwed, but they are at least declining gracefully. The RIAA and MPAA would make us breathe through tubes if they could.

唱片公司和电影制片厂采取的那些疯狂法律手段，就带有这种味道。报纸和杂志同样处境艰难，但至少它们正在体面地衰落。而RIAA和MPAA若有可能，就会强迫我们通过管道呼吸。

Ultimately it comes down to common sense. When you’re abusing the legal system by trying to use mass lawsuits against randomly chosen people as a form of exemplary punishment, or lobbying for laws that would break the Internet if they passed, that’s ipso facto evidence you’re using a definition of property that doesn’t work.

归根结底，这关乎常识。当你滥用法律体系，试图通过对随机挑选的人发起大规模诉讼来杀鸡儆猴，或者游说通过一旦实施就会摧毁互联网的法律时，这本身就证明你所采用的财产定义是行不通的。

This is where it’s helpful to have working democracies and multiple sovereign countries. If the world had a single, autocratic government, the labels and studios could buy laws making the definition of property be whatever they wanted. But fortunately there are still some countries that are not copyright colonies of the US, and even in the US, politicians still seem to be afraid of actual voters, in sufficient numbers. [3]

此时，拥有运转良好的民主制度和多个主权国家就显得尤为重要。如果全世界只有一个专制政府，唱片公司和制片厂就可以花钱买通法律，让财产的定义变成他们想要的任何样子。但幸运的是，仍有一些国家并非美国的“版权殖民地”，即便在美国，政客们似乎也仍然畏惧足够数量的真实选民。[3]

The people running the US may not like it when voters or other countries refuse to bend to their will, but ultimately it’s in all our interest that there’s not a single point of attack for people trying to warp the law to serve their own purposes. Private property is an extremely useful idea — arguably one of our greatest inventions. So far, each new definition of it has brought us increasing material wealth. [4] It seems reasonable to suppose the newest one will too. It would be a disaster if we all had to keep running an obsolete version just because a few powerful people were too lazy to upgrade.

美国的掌权者或许不喜欢选民或其他国家拒绝屈从于他们的意志，但归根结底，对我们所有人而言，重要的是不能让那些试图扭曲法律以谋私利的人拥有单一的攻击点。私有财产是一个极其有用的概念——甚至可以说是我们最伟大的发明之一。迄今为止，每一次对它的重新定义都为我们带来了日益增长的物质财富。[4] 有理由相信，最新的定义也将如此。如果仅仅因为少数有权势的人懒得升级，就迫使我们所有人继续运行一个过时的版本，那将是一场灾难。

Notes
注释

[1] If you want to learn more about hunter gatherers I strongly recommend Elizabeth Marshall Thomas’s The Harmless People and The Old Way.
[1] 如果你想进一步了解狩猎采集者，我强烈推荐伊丽莎白·马歇尔·托马斯（Elizabeth Marshall Thomas）的《无害的人》（The Harmless People）和《旧日之道》（The Old Way）。

[2] Change in the definition of property is driven mostly by technological progress, however, and since technological progress is accelerating, so presumably will the rate of change in the definition of property. Which means it’s all the more important for societies to be able to respond gracefully to such changes, because they will come at an ever increasing rate.
[2] 然而，财产定义的变化主要由技术进步推动；既然技术进步正在加速，财产定义的变化速度很可能也会随之加快。这意味着社会更需要具备优雅应对这类变化的能力，因为变化将以越来越快的速度到来。

[3] As far as I know, the term “copyright colony” was first used by Myles Peterson.
[3] 据我所知，“版权殖民地”（copyright colony）一词最早由迈尔斯·彼得森（Myles Peterson）提出。

[4] The state of technology isn’t simply a function of the definition of property. They each constrain the other. But that being so, you can’t mess with the definition of property without affecting (and probably harming) the state of technology. The history of the USSR offers a vivid illustration of that.
[4] 技术的发展状态并不仅仅由财产定义决定，二者相互制约。因此，你不可能随意改动财产定义而不影响（很可能损害）技术的发展状态。苏联的历史就生动地说明了这一点。

Thanks to Sam Altman and Geoff Ralston for reading drafts of this.
感谢山姆·阿尔特曼（Sam Altman）和杰夫·拉尔斯顿（Geoff Ralston）阅读本文草稿。

entry.title: 令人望而生畏的雄心勃勃的创业点子
entry.content:
Frighteningly Ambitious Startup Ideas

令人望而生畏的雄心勃勃的创业点子

原文链接: https://paulgraham.com/ambitious.html

March 2012

One of the more surprising things I’ve noticed while working on Y Combinator is how frightening the most ambitious startup ideas are. In this essay I’m going to demonstrate this phenomenon by describing some. Any one of them could make you a billionaire. That might sound like an attractive prospect, and yet when I describe these ideas you may notice you find yourself shrinking away from them.

我在参与 Y Combinator 工作时注意到一件颇为出人意料的事：最具雄心的创业点子往往令人望而生畏。在本文中，我将通过描述其中一些点子来展示这一现象。这些点子中的任何一个都可能让你成为亿万富翁。这听起来似乎极具吸引力，但当你听到我对这些点子的描述时，可能会发现自己下意识地退缩。

Don’t worry, it’s not a sign of weakness. Arguably it’s a sign of sanity. The biggest startup ideas are terrifying. And not just because they’d be a lot of work. The biggest ideas seem to threaten your identity: you wonder if you’d have enough ambition to carry them through.

别担心，这并非软弱的表现；甚至可以说，这恰恰是理智的体现。最宏大的创业点子确实令人恐惧——不仅因为它们需要付出巨大努力，更因为它们似乎会威胁到你的自我认同：你会怀疑自己是否拥有足够的雄心去坚持到底。

There’s a scene in Being John Malkovich where the nerdy hero encounters a very attractive, sophisticated woman. She says to him:
Here’s the thing: If you ever got me, you wouldn’t have a clue what to do with me.
That’s what these ideas say to us.

电影《傀儡人生》（Being John Malkovich）中有这样一个场景：书呆子主角邂逅了一位极具魅力又世故的女人，她对他说：
“事情是这样的：就算你真得到了我，你也不知道该怎么对待我。”
这些创业点子对我们说的正是这句话。

This phenomenon is one of the most important things you can understand about startups. [1] You’d expect big startup ideas to be attractive, but actually they tend to repel you. And that has a bunch of consequences. It means these ideas are invisible to most people who try to think of startup ideas, because their subconscious filters them out. Even the most ambitious people are probably best off approaching them obliquely.

这一现象是你理解创业公司时最重要的认知之一。[1] 你或许以为宏大的创业点子应该极具吸引力，但实际上它们往往会让人本能地排斥。这带来一系列后果：大多数人在试图构思创业点子时根本看不到这些想法，因为他们的潜意识会自动将其过滤掉。即便是最有雄心的人，或许也最好采取迂回的方式去接近它们。

A New Search Engine

一个新的搜索引擎

The best ideas are just on the right side of impossible. I don’t know if this one is possible, but there are signs it might be. Making a new search engine means competing with Google, and recently I’ve noticed some cracks in their fortress.

最好的点子往往就处在“不可能”的边缘。我不确定这个点子是否可行，但已有迹象表明它或许可行。打造一个新的搜索引擎意味着要与谷歌竞争，而最近我注意到谷歌这座堡垒上出现了一些裂痕。

The point when it became clear to me that Microsoft had lost their way was when they decided to get into the search business. That was not a natural move for Microsoft. They did it because they were afraid of Google, and Google was in the search business. But this meant (a) Google was now setting Microsoft’s agenda, and (b) Microsoft’s agenda consisted of stuff they weren’t good at.

我意识到微软迷失方向的那一刻，就是他们决定进军搜索业务之时。这对微软来说并非自然之举。他们这么做是因为害怕谷歌，而谷歌当时正从事搜索业务。但这意味着两点：(a) 谷歌开始主导微软的议程，(b) 微软的议程变成了他们并不擅长的事情。

Microsoft : Google :: Google : Facebook.

微软之于谷歌，正如谷歌之于 Facebook。

That does not by itself mean there’s room for a new search engine, but lately when using Google search I’ve found myself nostalgic for the old days, when Google was true to its own slightly aspy self. Google used to give me a page of the right answers, fast, with no clutter. Now the results seem inspired by the Scientologist principle that what’s true is what’s true for you. And the pages don’t have the clean, sparse feel they used to. Google search results used to look like the output of a Unix utility. Now if I accidentally put the cursor in the wrong place, anything might happen.

这本身并不意味着新搜索引擎就有机会，但最近使用谷歌搜索时，我发现自己开始怀念过去的日子——那时谷歌忠于自己那种略带“阿斯伯格”气质的本色。过去的谷歌会快速给我一页精准、无杂乱信息的答案。如今的搜索结果却仿佛受到山达基教原则的启发：“对你而言真实的就是真实的”。网页也不再拥有昔日那种干净、简洁的感觉。谷歌的搜索结果曾经看起来像 Unix 工具的输出；而现在，只要我不小心把光标点错位置，任何事情都可能发生。

The way to win here is to build the search engine all the hackers use. A search engine whose users consisted of the top 10,000 hackers and no one else would be in a very powerful position despite its small size, just as Google was when it was that search engine. And for the first time in over a decade the idea of switching seems thinkable to me.

取胜之道在于打造一个所有黑客都会使用的搜索引擎。即使用户仅限于全球顶尖的一万名黑客，这个引擎也将因其影响力而占据强势地位——就像当年谷歌最初也只是黑客们的首选一样。十多年来，我第一次觉得切换搜索引擎这件事变得可以想象了。

Since anyone capable of starting this company is one of those 10,000 hackers, the route is at least straightforward: make the search engine you yourself want. Feel free to make it excessively hackerish. Make it really good for code search, for example. Would you like search queries to be Turing complete? Anything that gets you those 10,000 users is ipso facto good.

既然任何有能力创办这家公司的人都属于那万名黑客之一，那么路径至少是明确的：打造你自己想要的搜索引擎。不妨让它极度“黑客化”——比如让它在代码搜索方面表现卓越。你希望搜索查询具备图灵完备性吗？只要能吸引到这万名用户，任何做法本质上都是好的。

Don’t worry if something you want to do will constrain you in the long term, because if you don’t get that initial core of users, there won’t be a long term. If you can just build something that you and your friends genuinely prefer to Google, you’re already about 10% of the way to an IPO, just as Facebook was (though they probably didn’t realize it) when they got all the Harvard undergrads.

不必担心你当下想做的事会在长期限制你的发展，因为如果你拿不到最初的这批核心用户，根本就不会有“长期”可言。只要你能做出你和朋友们真心更喜欢、胜过谷歌的产品，你就已经完成了通往 IPO 的约 10% 的路程——就像当年 Facebook 在拿下所有哈佛本科生时那样（尽管他们当时可能并未意识到这一点）。

Replace Email

取代电子邮件

Email was not designed to be used the way we use it now. Email is not a messaging protocol. It’s a todo list. Or rather, my inbox is a todo list, and email is the way things get onto it. But it is a disastrously bad todo list.

电子邮件最初并非为今天这种使用方式而设计。电子邮件并不是一种消息协议，而是一份待办事项清单。更准确地说，我的收件箱是一份待办清单，而电子邮件只是把事项添加进去的方式。但它是一份灾难性的糟糕待办清单。

I’m open to different types of solutions to this problem, but I suspect that tweaking the inbox is not enough, and that email has to be replaced with a new protocol. This new protocol should be a todo list protocol, not a messaging protocol, although there is a degenerate case where what someone wants you to do is: read the following text.

我对解决这个问题持开放态度，但我怀疑仅仅调整收件箱是不够的，必须用一种新协议来取代电子邮件。这个新协议应当是一种待办事项协议，而非消息协议——尽管存在一种退化情况：对方希望你做的事情仅仅是“阅读以下文字”。

As a todo list protocol, the new protocol should give more power to the recipient than email does. I want there to be more restrictions on what someone can put on my todo list. And when someone can put something on my todo list, I want them to tell me more about what they want from me. Do they want me to do something beyond just reading some text? How important is it? (There obviously has to be some mechanism to prevent people from saying everything is important.) When does it have to be done?

作为一种待办事项协议，新协议应比电子邮件赋予接收者更多控制权。我希望对他人能往我的待办清单上添加什么内容施加更多限制。当有人确实有权向我的清单添加任务时，我也希望他们能更清楚地说明对我有何期待：他们是否希望我做的不只是阅读一段文字？这件事有多重要？（显然需要某种机制防止所有人都声称自己的事“极其重要”。）这件事何时必须完成？

This is one of those ideas that’s like an irresistible force meeting an immovable object. On one hand, entrenched protocols are impossible to replace. On the other, it seems unlikely that people in 100 years will still be living in the same email hell we do now. And if email is going to get replaced eventually, why not now?

这是一个典型的“不可阻挡的力量撞上不可移动的物体”式的想法。一方面，根深蒂固的协议几乎不可能被取代；另一方面，很难想象一百年后的人们还会像我们今天这样深陷电子邮件的地狱之中。既然电子邮件终将被取代，为何不就是现在？

If you do it right, you may be able to avoid the usual chicken and egg problem new protocols face, because some of the most powerful people in the world will be among the first to switch to it. They’re all at the mercy of email too.

如果你做对了，或许能避开新协议通常面临的“先有鸡还是先有蛋”的困境，因为世界上一些最有影响力的人很可能率先切换到你的新系统——他们同样深受电子邮件之苦。

Whatever you build, make it fast. GMail has become painfully slow. [2] If you made something no better than GMail, but fast, that alone would let you start to pull users away from GMail.

无论你构建什么，请务必让它速度快。Gmail 已经变得痛苦地缓慢。[2] 即使你做出的东西在功能上并不比 Gmail 更好，只要速度更快，就足以开始从 Gmail 手中抢走用户。

GMail is slow because Google can’t afford to spend a lot on it. But people will pay for this. I’d have no problem paying $50 a month. Considering how much time I spend in email, it’s kind of scary to think how much I’d be justified in paying. At least $1000 a month. If I spend several hours a day reading and writing email, that would be a cheap way to make my life better.

Gmail 之所以慢，是因为谷歌无法在它身上投入太多资源。但人们愿意为此付费。我每月付 50 美元毫无压力。考虑到我在邮件上花费的时间之多，细想一下我其实理应支付的金额甚至有点吓人——至少每月 1000 美元。如果我每天花数小时读写邮件，那么这笔钱就是改善生活的廉价投资。

Replace Universities

取代大学

People are all over this idea lately, and I think they’re onto something. I’m reluctant to suggest that an institution that’s been around for a millennium is finished just because of some mistakes they made in the last few decades, but certainly in the last few decades US universities seem to have been headed down the wrong path. One could do a lot better for a lot less money.

最近很多人都在讨论这个想法，我认为他们确实抓住了某些关键点。我并不愿轻易断言一个已存在千年的机构仅仅因为过去几十年犯了些错误就走向终结，但不可否认的是，近几十年来美国大学似乎确实走上了歧路。人们完全可以用少得多的钱做得好得多。

I don’t think universities will disappear. They won’t be replaced wholesale. They’ll just lose the de facto monopoly on certain types of learning that they once had. There will be many different ways to learn different things, and some may look quite different from universities. Y Combinator itself is arguably one of them.

我认为大学不会消失，也不会被整体取代，而是会失去其过去在某些类型学习上的事实垄断地位。未来将出现多种多样的学习方式，其中一些可能与传统大学大相径庭。Y Combinator 本身或许就可以算作其中之一。

Learning is such a big problem that changing the way people do it will have a wave of secondary effects. For example, the name of the university one went to is treated by a lot of people (correctly or not) as a credential in its own right. If learning breaks up into many little pieces, credentialling may separate from it. There may even need to be replacements for campus social life (and oddly enough, YC even has aspects of that).

学习是一个如此庞大的问题，以至于改变人们的学习方式将引发一连串连锁反应。例如，很多人（无论对错）都将一个人所毕业的大学名称本身视为一种资历凭证。如果学习被拆解成许多小块，认证体系或许会与学习过程分离。甚至校园社交生活也可能需要替代方案（奇怪的是，YC 本身就具备这方面的某些特征）。

You could replace high schools too, but there you face bureaucratic obstacles that would slow down a startup. Universities seem the place to start.

你也可以尝试取代高中，但在那里你会面临官僚体制的障碍，会拖慢初创公司的步伐。相比之下，大学似乎是更好的切入点。

Internet Drama

网络剧集

Hollywood has been slow to embrace the Internet. That was a mistake, because I think we can now call a winner in the race between delivery mechanisms, and it is the Internet, not cable.

好莱坞迟迟未能拥抱互联网，这是个错误。因为我认为，在内容分发渠道的竞争中，如今胜负已分：赢家是互联网，而非有线电视。

A lot of the reason is the horribleness of cable clients, also known as TVs. Our family didn’t wait for Apple TV. We hated our last TV so much that a few months ago we replaced it with an iMac bolted to the wall. It’s a little inconvenient to control it with a wireless mouse, but the overall experience is much better than the nightmare UI we had to deal with before.

很大程度上是因为有线电视终端（也就是电视机）体验太差。我们家甚至没等到 Apple TV 出现。我们对上一台电视厌恶至极，几个月前干脆把它换成了一台固定在墙上的 iMac。虽然用无线鼠标操作稍显不便，但整体体验远胜于之前那个噩梦般的用户界面。

Some of the attention people currently devote to watching movies and TV can be stolen by things that seem completely unrelated, like social networking apps. More can be stolen by things that are a little more closely related, like games. But there will probably always remain some residual demand for conventional drama, where you sit passively and watch as a plot happens. So how do you deliver drama via the Internet? Whatever you make will have to be on a larger scale than Youtube clips. When people sit down to watch a show, they want to know what they’re going to get: either part of a series with familiar characters, or a single longer “movie” whose basic premise they know in advance.

人们目前用于观看电影和电视的部分注意力，已经被一些看似完全无关的事物夺走，比如社交网络应用；更多注意力则被稍相关些的事物（如游戏）所占据。但很可能始终会存在对传统戏剧形式的残余需求——即观众被动地坐着，看着剧情展开。那么，如何通过互联网来提供这种戏剧内容呢？无论你制作什么，其规模都必须超越 YouTube 短视频。当人们坐下来观看节目时，他们希望知道自己将看到什么：要么是拥有熟悉角色的系列剧集的一部分，要么是一部他们事先已了解基本前提的较长“电影”。

There are two ways delivery and payment could play out. Either some company like Netflix or Apple will be the app store for entertainment, and you’ll reach audiences through them. Or the would-be app stores will be too overreaching, or too technically inflexible, and companies will arise to supply payment and streaming a la carte to the producers of drama. If that’s the way things play out, there will also be a need for such infrastructure companies.

内容分发与付费模式可能有两种发展路径：要么由 Netflix 或 Apple 这样的公司成为娱乐领域的“应用商店”，你通过它们触达观众；要么这些潜在的“应用商店”因过度控制或技术上过于僵化，从而催生出专门向戏剧内容创作者提供按需付费与流媒体服务的新公司。如果后一种情况成真，这类基础设施公司也将随之产生。

The Next Steve Jobs

下一个史蒂夫·乔布斯

I was talking recently to someone who knew Apple well, and I asked him if the people now running the company would be able to keep creating new things the way Apple had under Steve Jobs. His answer was simply “no.” I already feared that would be the answer. I asked more to see how he’d qualify it. But he didn’t qualify it at all. No, there will be no more great new stuff beyond whatever’s currently in the pipeline. Apple’s revenues may continue to rise for a long time, but as Microsoft shows, revenue is a lagging indicator in the technology business.

我最近和一位非常了解苹果的人交谈，问他如今掌舵苹果的团队是否还能像乔布斯时代那样持续创造新产品。他的回答很简单：“不能。”我其实已经预料到这个答案，问这个问题更多是想看他如何限定或解释。但他完全没有做任何限定。不会了——除了当前产品线中已有的东西外，不会再有伟大的新产品问世。苹果的收入或许还会持续增长很长时间，但正如微软的例子所示，在科技行业，收入只是一个滞后指标。

So if Apple’s not going to make the next iPad, who is? None of the existing players. None of them are run by product visionaries, and empirically you can’t seem to get those by hiring them. Empirically the way you get a product visionary as CEO is for him to found the company and not get fired. So the company that creates the next wave of hardware is probably going to have to be a startup.

那么，如果苹果不再制造下一台 iPad，谁会来做？现有的大公司都不会。它们没有一位是由产品愿景家领导的，而且经验表明，你无法通过招聘获得这样的人。经验告诉我们，要让一位产品愿景家担任 CEO，唯一可靠的方式就是让他自己创立公司，并且不被解雇。因此，引领下一波硬件浪潮的公司很可能是一家初创企业。

I realize it sounds preposterously ambitious for a startup to try to become as big as Apple. But no more ambitious than it was for Apple to become as big as Apple, and they did it. Plus a startup taking on this problem now has an advantage the original Apple didn’t: the example of Apple. Steve Jobs has shown us what’s possible. That helps would-be successors both directly, as Roger Bannister did, by showing how much better you can do than people did before, and indirectly, as Augustus did, by lodging the idea in users’ minds that a single person could unroll the future for them. [3]

我知道，一家初创公司试图成长为苹果那样的巨头听起来荒谬地雄心勃勃。但这并不比当年苹果成长为今天的苹果更雄心勃勃——而他们确实做到了。此外，如今尝试解决这个问题的初创公司还拥有一项初代苹果所没有的优势：苹果自身的榜样。史蒂夫·乔布斯向我们展示了什么是可能的。这既直接帮助了潜在的继任者（就像罗杰·班尼斯特打破四分钟一英里纪录，证明人类可以做得远超以往），也间接地在用户心中植入了一个观念：一个人可以为他们展开未来（就像奥古斯都所做的那样）。[3]

Now Steve is gone there’s a vacuum we can all feel. If a new company led boldly into the future of hardware, users would follow. The CEO of that company, the “next Steve Jobs,” might not measure up to Steve Jobs. But he wouldn’t have to. He’d just have to do a better job than Samsung and HP and Nokia, and that seems pretty doable.

如今乔布斯已逝，留下了一个我们都能感受到的真空。如果有一家新公司大胆引领硬件的未来，用户自会追随。这家公司的 CEO——“下一个史蒂夫·乔布斯”——或许无法真正比肩乔布斯本人，但他其实也不需要做到。他只需要比三星、惠普和诺基亚做得更好就行，而这似乎相当可行。

Bring Back Moore’s Law

重振摩尔定律

The last 10 years have reminded us what Moore’s Law actually says. Till about 2002 you could safely misinterpret it as promising that clock speeds would double every 18 months. Actually what it says is that circuit densities will double every 18 months. It used to seem pedantic to point that out. Not any more. Intel can no longer give us faster CPUs, just more of them.

过去十年提醒了我们摩尔定律的真实含义。大约在 2002 年之前，人们可以安全地误以为它承诺的是处理器主频每 18 个月翻倍。但实际上，它说的是电路密度每 18 个月翻倍。过去指出这一点似乎显得吹毛求疵，如今却不再是了。英特尔再也无法给我们更快的 CPU，只能给我们更多的 CPU 核心。

This Moore’s Law is not as good as the old one. Moore’s Law used to mean that if your software was slow, all you had to do was wait, and the inexorable progress of hardware would solve your problems. Now if your software is slow you have to rewrite it to do more things in parallel, which is a lot more work than waiting.

如今的摩尔定律不如从前那般美好。过去，摩尔定律意味着如果你的软件运行缓慢，只需等待即可——硬件不可阻挡的进步会替你解决问题。而现在，如果你的软件慢，你就得重写代码，让它能并行处理更多任务，这可比单纯等待费力得多。

It would be great if a startup could give us something of the old Moore’s Law back, by writing software that could make a large number of CPUs look to the developer like one very fast CPU. There are several ways to approach this problem. The most ambitious is to try to do it automatically: to write a compiler that will parallelize our code for us. There’s a name for this compiler, the sufficiently smart compiler, and it is a byword for impossibility. But is it really impossible? Is there no configuration of the bits in memory of a present day computer that is this compiler? If you really think so, you should try to prove it, because that would be an interesting result. And if it’s not impossible but simply very hard, it might be worth trying to write it. The expected value would be high even if the chance of succeeding was low.

如果一家初创公司能通过编写某种软件，让大量 CPU 在开发者眼中看起来像一个极快的单核 CPU，从而部分恢复旧日摩尔定律带来的便利，那就太棒了。解决这个问题有几种路径。最雄心勃勃的方式是尝试自动实现：开发一个能自动为我们并行化代码的编译器。人们给这种编译器起了个名字——“足够聪明的编译器”（the sufficiently smart compiler），它几乎成了“不可能”的代名词。但它真的不可能吗？难道当今计算机内存中的比特就无法构成这样一个编译器？如果你真这么认为，不妨试着去证明它，因为那将是一个有趣的结果。而如果它并非不可能，只是极其困难，那么尝试去编写它或许值得——即使成功概率很低，其期望价值依然很高。

The reason the expected value is so high is web services. If you could write software that gave programmers the convenience of the way things were in the old days, you could offer it to them as a web service. And that would in turn mean that you got practically all the users.

之所以期望价值如此之高，是因为网络服务（web services）。如果你能写出这样的软件，让程序员重新享受旧日那种便利，你就可以将其作为一项网络服务提供给他们。这样一来，你几乎就能获得全部用户。

Imagine there was another processor manufacturer that could still translate increased circuit densities into increased clock speeds. They’d take most of Intel’s business. And since web services mean that no one sees their processors anymore, by writing the sufficiently smart compiler you could create a situation indistinguishable from you being that manufacturer, at least for the server market.

想象一下，如果有另一家处理器制造商仍能将更高的电路密度转化为更高的主频，他们就会抢走英特尔大部分生意。而由于网络服务意味着用户不再直接接触底层处理器，那么只要你写出“足够聪明的编译器”，你就能创造出一种与成为那家制造商无异的局面——至少在服务器市场是如此。

The least ambitious way of approaching the problem is to start from the other end, and offer programmers more parallelizable Lego blocks to build programs out of, like Hadoop and MapReduce. Then the programmer still does much of the work of optimization.

最不雄心勃勃的解决方式是从另一端入手：为程序员提供更多可并行化的“乐高积木”来构建程序，比如 Hadoop 和 MapReduce。在这种情况下，程序员仍需承担大部分优化工作。

There’s an intriguing middle ground where you build a semi-automatic weapon—where there’s a human in the loop. You make something that looks to the user like the sufficiently smart compiler, but inside has people, using highly developed optimization tools to find and eliminate bottlenecks in users’ programs. These people might be your employees, or you might create a marketplace for optimization.

还存在一个引人入胜的中间地带：打造一种“半自动武器”——人在回路中。你对外呈现给用户的是“足够聪明的编译器”，但内部其实由人工操作，使用高度发达的优化工具来发现并消除用户程序中的瓶颈。这些人可以是你的雇员，也可以是你搭建的一个优化服务市场。

An optimization marketplace would be a way to generate the sufficiently smart compiler piecemeal, because participants would immediately start writing bots. It would be a curious state of affairs if you could get to the point where everything could be done by bots, because then you’d have made the sufficiently smart compiler, but no one person would have a complete copy of it.

一个优化市场可以逐步拼凑出“足够聪明的编译器”，因为参与者会立刻开始编写自动化机器人（bots）。如果最终达到所有工作都能由机器人完成的地步，那将是一种奇特的局面：你确实造出了“足够聪明的编译器”，但却没有任何一个人拥有它的完整副本。

I realize how crazy all this sounds. In fact, what I like about this idea is all the different ways in which it’s wrong. The whole idea of focusing on optimization is counter to the general trend in software development for the last several decades. Trying to write the sufficiently smart compiler is by definition a mistake. And even if it weren’t, compilers are the sort of software that’s supposed to be created by open source projects, not companies. Plus if this works it will deprive all the programmers who take pleasure in making multithreaded apps of so much amusing complexity. The forum troll I have by now internalized doesn’t even know where to begin in raising objections to this project. Now that’s what I call a startup idea.

我清楚这一切听起来有多疯狂。事实上，我喜欢这个点子的地方恰恰在于它在多个层面上都是“错误”的：专注于优化本身与过去几十年软件开发的整体趋势背道而驰；试图编写“足够聪明的编译器”从定义上就是个错误；即便不是错误，编译器这类软件本该由开源项目而非商业公司来开发；而且，如果它真成功了，还会剥夺那些以编写多线程应用为乐的程序员们所享受的复杂乐趣。我内心那个早已内化的论坛杠精甚至都不知道该从哪里开始反驳这个项目。这才叫真正的创业点子。

Ongoing Diagnosis

持续性诊断

But wait, here’s another that could face even greater resistance: ongoing, automatic medical diagnosis.

但等等，还有一个点子可能面临更大的阻力：持续、自动化的医疗诊断。

One of my tricks for generating startup ideas is to imagine the ways in which we’ll seem backward to future generations. And I’m pretty sure that to people 50 or 100 years in the future, it will seem barbaric that people in our era waited till they had symptoms to be diagnosed with conditions like heart disease and cancer.

我构思创业点子的一个技巧，就是想象未来几代人会如何看待我们今天的落后之处。我相当确信，对于 50 或 100 年后的人们来说，我们这个时代的人居然要等到出现症状才去诊断心脏病或癌症，会显得野蛮而荒谬。

For example, in 2004 Bill Clinton found he was feeling short of breath. Doctors discovered that several of his arteries were over 90% blocked and 3 days later he had a quadruple bypass. It seems reasonable to assume Bill Clinton has the best medical care available. And yet even he had to wait till his arteries were over 90% blocked to learn that the number was over 90%. Surely at some point in the future we’ll know these numbers the way we now know something like our weight. Ditto for cancer. It will seem preposterous to future generations that we wait till patients have physical symptoms to be diagnosed with cancer. Cancer will show up on some sort of radar screen immediately.

例如，2004 年比尔·克林顿感到呼吸急促，医生发现他的几条动脉堵塞超过 90%，三天后他就接受了四重搭桥手术。我们可以合理假设克林顿享有当今世界最好的医疗服务。然而即便是他，也必须等到动脉堵塞超过 90% 才知道这一数字。毫无疑问，未来某个时候，我们会像今天知道自己的体重一样，实时掌握这些健康数据。癌症也是如此。未来世代会认为，我们居然要等到患者出现身体症状才诊断癌症，简直荒唐至极。癌症会立即在某种“雷达屏幕”上显现出来。

(Of course, what shows up on the radar screen may be different from what we think of now as cancer. I wouldn’t be surprised if at any given time we have ten or even hundreds of microcancers going at once, none of which normally amount to anything.)

（当然，雷达屏幕上显示的内容可能与我们今天所理解的“癌症”有所不同。我毫不惊讶于我们体内可能随时存在十个甚至上百个微小癌灶，而其中绝大多数通常根本不会发展成问题。）

A lot of the obstacles to ongoing diagnosis will come from the fact that it’s going against the grain of the medical profession. The way medicine has always worked is that patients come to doctors with problems, and the doctors figure out what’s wrong. A lot of doctors don’t like the idea of going on the medical equivalent of what lawyers call a “fishing expedition,” where you go looking for problems without knowing what you’re looking for. They call the things that get discovered this way “incidentalomas,” and they are something of a nuisance.

持续性诊断面临的许多障碍，源于它与医学界根深蒂固的传统背道而驰。传统医疗模式始终是：患者带着问题来找医生，医生再设法找出病因。许多医生并不喜欢这种类似律师所说的“钓鱼式调查”（fishing expedition）——即在没有明确目标的情况下主动搜寻问题。他们将这种方式偶然发现的异常称为“偶发瘤”（incidentalomas），并视其为一种麻烦。

For example, a friend of mine once had her brain scanned as part of a study. She was horrified when the doctors running the study discovered what appeared to be a large tumor. After further testing, it turned out to be a harmless cyst. But it cost her a few days of terror. A lot of doctors worry that if you start scanning people with no symptoms, you’ll get this on a giant scale: a huge number of false alarms that make patients panic and require expensive and perhaps even dangerous tests to resolve. But I think that’s just an artifact of current limitations. If people were scanned all the time and we got better at deciding what was a real problem, my friend would have known about this cyst her whole life and known it was harmless, just as we do a birthmark.

例如，我一位朋友曾因参与一项研究而接受脑部扫描。当研究人员发现一个疑似大型肿瘤的影像时，她惊恐万分。但经过进一步检查，结果只是个无害的囊肿。尽管如此，那几天的恐惧却真实存在。许多医生担心，如果对无症状人群进行大规模筛查，这类情况会以巨大规模出现：大量假阳性警报引发患者恐慌，并迫使他们接受昂贵、甚至有风险的后续检查来排除疑虑。但我认为，这不过是当前技术局限性的产物。如果人们能被持续监测，且我们能更准确地区分真正的问题与良性异常，那么我这位朋友可能从小就知道自己有个无害的囊肿——就像我们知道身上有颗痣一样平常。

There is room for a lot of startups here. In addition to the technical obstacles all startups face, and the bureaucratic obstacles all medical startups face, they’ll be going against thousands of years of medical tradition. But it will happen, and it will be a great thing—so great that people in the future will feel as sorry for us as we do for the generations that lived before anaesthesia and antibiotics.

这里蕴藏着大量创业机会。除了所有初创公司都要面对的技术挑战，以及所有医疗初创公司都要应对的官僚障碍之外，这些企业还将挑战延续数千年的医学传统。但变革终将发生，而且会是一件了不起的事——其意义之大，以至于未来的人们看待我们时，会像我们今天看待麻醉术和抗生素发明前的世代那样充满怜悯。

Tactics
Let me conclude with some tactical advice. If you want to take on a problem as big as the ones I’ve discussed, don’t make a direct frontal attack on it. Don’t say, for example, that you’re going to replace email. If you do that you raise too many expectations. Your employees and investors will constantly be asking “are we there yet?” and you’ll have an army of haters waiting to see you fail. Just say you’re building todo-list software. That sounds harmless. People can notice you’ve replaced email when it’s a fait accompli. [4]

战术建议
让我以一些战术性建议作结。如果你想解决像上述那样宏大的问题，切勿正面强攻。比如，不要一上来就说“我们要取代电子邮件”。那样做会引发过高的预期：你的员工和投资人会不断追问“我们到了吗？”，同时还会招来一群等着看你失败的反对者。不如只说你在开发一款待办事项（todo-list）软件——听起来人畜无害。等你真的取代了电子邮件时，人们自然会意识到，但那时木已成舟。[4]

Empirically, the way to do really big things seems to be to start with deceptively small things. Want to dominate microcomputer software? Start by writing a Basic interpreter for a machine with a few thousand users. Want to make the universal web site? Start by building a site for Harvard undergrads to stalk one another.

经验表明，做成真正伟大的事业，往往始于看似微不足道的小事。想主导微型计算机软件？那就先为一台只有几千用户的机器写一个 BASIC 解释器。想打造一个全球通用的网站？那就先做个哈佛本科生互相窥探的社交平台。

Empirically, it’s not just for other people that you need to start small. You need to for your own sake. Neither Bill Gates nor Mark Zuckerberg knew at first how big their companies were going to get. All they knew was that they were onto something. Maybe it’s a bad idea to have really big ambitions initially, because the bigger your ambition, the longer it’s going to take, and the further you project into the future, the more likely you’ll get it wrong.

而且，从小处着手不仅是为了向外界低调行事，更是为了你自己。比尔·盖茨和马克·扎克伯格最初都不知道自己公司最终会变得多么庞大。他们只知道，自己抓住了某种有价值的东西。或许，一开始就怀抱过于宏大的抱负反而是有害的——因为目标越大，所需时间越长；而你对未来预判得越远，出错的可能性就越高。

I think the way to use these big ideas is not to try to identify a precise point in the future and then ask yourself how to get from here to there, like the popular image of a visionary. You’ll be better off if you operate like Columbus and just head in a general westerly direction. Don’t try to construct the future like a building, because your current blueprint is almost certainly mistaken. Start with something you know works, and when you expand, expand westward.

我认为，运用这些宏大构想的正确方式，并非先锁定未来某个精确目标，再倒推路径——那只是大众对“远见者”的刻板印象。你更应该像哥伦布那样，只需大致朝西航行即可。不要试图像建造房屋一样去“设计”未来，因为你现在的蓝图几乎肯定是错的。从你知道行得通的小事做起，当你扩张时，就向西扩张。

The popular image of the visionary is someone with a clear view of the future, but empirically it may be better to have a blurry one.

大众心目中的“远见者”总被描绘成对未来有清晰图景的人，但经验表明，拥有模糊愿景的人反而可能走得更远。

Notes

[1] It’s also one of the most important things VCs fail to understand about startups. Most expect founders to walk in with a clear plan for the future, and judge them based on that. Few consciously realize that in the biggest successes there is the least correlation between the initial plan and what the startup eventually becomes.
[1] 这也是风险投资人（VCs）对初创公司最常误解的关键点之一。大多数投资人期望创始人带着一份清晰的未来规划走进会议室，并据此评判他们。但很少有人意识到：在那些最成功的创业案例中，最初的计划与公司最终形态之间的关联往往是最弱的。
[2] This sentence originally read “GMail is painfully slow.” Thanks to Paul Buchheit for the correction.
[2] 原文此处曾写道：“Gmail 慢得令人痛苦。”感谢 Paul Buchheit（Gmail 创始人）指出并纠正这一说法。
[3] Roger Bannister is famous as the first person to run a mile in under 4 minutes. But his world record only lasted 46 days. Once he showed it could be done, lots of others followed. Ten years later Jim Ryun ran a 3:59 mile as a high school junior.
[3] 罗杰·班尼斯特（Roger Bannister）因成为首位在四分钟内跑完一英里的人而闻名。但他的世界纪录仅保持了46天。一旦他证明这是可能的，大量后来者便迅速跟进。十年后，高中生吉姆·赖恩（Jim Ryun）以3分59秒的成绩跑完一英里。
[4] If you want to be the next Apple, maybe you don’t even want to start with consumer electronics. Maybe at first you make something hackers use. Or you make something popular but apparently unimportant, like a headset or router. All you need is a bridgehead.
[4] 如果你想成为下一个苹果，或许一开始根本不必涉足消费电子产品。也许你最初做的是黑客群体爱用的工具，或者看似微不足道却广受欢迎的产品——比如耳机或路由器。你所需要的，只是一个滩头阵地（bridgehead）。

致谢
感谢 Sam Altman、Trevor Blackwell、Paul Buchheit、Patrick Collison、Aaron Iba、Jessica Livingston、Robert Morris、Harj Taggar 和 Garry Tan 阅读本文初稿。

entry.title: 致足智多谋者
entry.content:
A Word to the Resourceful

原文链接: https://paulgraham.com/word.html

January 2012

A year ago I noticed a pattern in the least successful startups we’d funded: they all seemed hard to talk to. It felt as if there was some kind of wall between us. I could never quite tell if they understood what I was saying.

一年前，我注意到我们所投资的最不成功的初创公司中存在一种模式：它们似乎都很难沟通。感觉我们之间仿佛隔着一堵墙。我始终无法确定他们是否真正理解了我说的话。

This caught my attention because earlier we’d noticed a pattern among the most successful startups, and it seemed to hinge on a different quality. We found the startups that did best were the ones with the sort of founders about whom we’d say “they can take care of themselves.” The startups that do best are fire-and-forget in the sense that all you have to do is give them a lead, and they’ll close it, whatever type of lead it is. When they’re raising money, for example, you can do the initial intros knowing that if you wanted to you could stop thinking about it at that point. You won’t have to babysit the round to make sure it happens. That type of founder is going to come back with the money; the only question is how much on what terms.

这引起了我的注意，因为此前我们已在最成功的初创公司中观察到另一种模式，而这种模式似乎取决于一种不同的特质。我们发现，表现最好的初创公司，其创始人正是那种我们会说“他们能自己搞定一切”的人。这些最成功的初创公司就像“发射后不管”的武器——你只需给他们一个线索，无论是什么类型的线索，他们都能搞定。例如，在融资时，你只需做最初的引荐，之后便可完全放心；即便你从此不再过问，融资也一定会完成。这类创始人一定会带回资金，唯一的问题只是金额多少以及条款如何。

It seemed odd that the outliers at the two ends of the spectrum could be detected by what appeared to be unrelated tests. You’d expect that if the founders at one end were distinguished by the presence of quality x, at the other end they’d be distinguished by lack of x. Was there some kind of inverse relation between resourcefulness and being hard to talk to?

奇怪的是，光谱两端的极端案例竟能通过看似无关的测试被识别出来。人们通常会认为，如果一端的创始人以具备某种特质X为标志，那么另一端就应以缺乏该特质X为特征。那么，足智多谋与难以沟通之间是否存在某种反向关联？

It turns out there is, and the key to the mystery is the old adage “a word to the wise is sufficient.” Because this phrase is not only overused, but overused in an indirect way (by prepending the subject to some advice), most people who’ve heard it don’t know what it means. What it means is that if someone is wise, all you have to do is say one word to them, and they’ll understand immediately. You don’t have to explain in detail; they’ll chase down all the implications.

事实的确如此，而解开这个谜题的关键在于那句老话：“智者一言足矣”（a word to the wise is sufficient）。由于这句话不仅被过度使用，而且常被间接地使用（比如在建议前加上主语），大多数听过它的人其实并不真正理解其含义。它的意思是：如果一个人足够明智，你只需说一个词，他就能立刻领会全部含义。你无需详加解释，他会自行追索所有隐含的推论。

In much the same way that all you have to do is give the right sort of founder a one line intro to a VC, and he’ll chase down the money. That’s the connection. Understanding all the implications — even the inconvenient implications — of what someone tells you is a subset of resourcefulness. It’s conversational resourcefulness.

这与你只需给合适的创始人一句简短的风投引荐，他就能追回资金的情况如出一辙。这就是其中的联系。理解他人话语中的全部含义——哪怕是那些令人不适的含义——正是足智多谋的一个子集，可称之为“对话中的足智多谋”。

Like real world resourcefulness, conversational resourcefulness often means doing things you don’t want to. Chasing down all the implications of what’s said to you can sometimes lead to uncomfortable conclusions. The best word to describe the failure to do so is probably “denial,” though that seems a bit too narrow. A better way to describe the situation would be to say that the unsuccessful founders had the sort of conservatism that comes from weakness. They traversed idea space as gingerly as a very old person traverses the physical world. [1]

如同现实世界中的足智多谋一样，对话中的足智多谋也常常意味着去做那些你不愿做的事。追索他人话语的所有含义，有时会得出令人不安的结论。描述这种失败行为最贴切的词或许是“否认”（denial），尽管这个词似乎略显狭隘。更准确的说法是，那些不成功的创始人表现出一种源于软弱的保守主义。他们在思想空间中前行时，就像一位高龄老人在物理世界中小心翼翼地挪步一般。[1]

The unsuccessful founders weren’t stupid. Intellectually they were as capable as the successful founders of following all the implications of what one said to them. They just weren’t eager to.

这些不成功的创始人并不愚蠢。从智力上讲，他们完全有能力像成功创始人那样理解他人话语中的全部含义。只是他们缺乏这样做的意愿。

So being hard to talk to was not what was killing the unsuccessful startups. It was a sign of an underlying lack of resourcefulness. That’s what was killing them. As well as failing to chase down the implications of what was said to them, the unsuccessful founders would also fail to chase down funding, and users, and sources of new ideas. But the most immediate evidence I had that something was amiss was that I couldn’t talk to them.

因此，真正扼杀这些不成功初创公司的，并非“难以沟通”本身，而是这一现象背后所反映出的根本性不足：缺乏足智多谋。正是这一点导致了它们的失败。除了不去深究他人话语的全部含义之外，这些不成功的创始人同样无法积极争取资金、用户和新点子的来源。但对我来说，最直接的警示信号就是：我无法与他们顺畅交流。

Notes

注释
[1] A YC partner wrote:
My feeling with the bad groups is that coming into office hours, they’ve already decided what they’re going to do and everything I say is being put through an internal process in their heads, which either desperately tries to munge what I’ve said into something that conforms with their decision or just outright dismisses it and creates a rationalization for doing so. They may not even be conscious of this process but that’s what I think is happening when you say something to bad groups and they have that glazed over look. I don’t think it’s confusion or lack of understanding per se, it’s this internal process at work.
With the good groups, you can tell that everything you say is being looked at with fresh eyes and even if it’s dismissed, it’s because of some logical reason e.g. “we already tried that” or “from speaking to our users that isn’t what they’d like,” etc. Those groups never have that glazed over look.

[1] 一位 YC 合伙人写道：
我对那些表现不佳的团队的感受是：他们在进入办公时间之前就已经决定了要做什么，而我说的每一句话都会在他们脑海中经过一个内部处理过程——要么拼命把我的话扭曲成符合他们既定决策的内容，要么干脆直接否定，并为此找一套合理的解释。他们甚至可能并未意识到这一过程的存在，但我认为，当你对这些糟糕的团队说话而他们眼神呆滞时，正是这种内在机制在起作用。我认为这并非源于困惑或理解力不足，而是这种内在处理机制在作祟。
而对于那些优秀的团队，你能明显感觉到他们是以全新的眼光审视你说的每句话；即使他们否定了某些建议，也是出于合乎逻辑的理由，比如“我们已经试过了”或“根据与用户的沟通，他们并不想要这个”，等等。这些团队从来不会有那种呆滞的眼神。

Thanks to Sam Altman, Patrick Collison, Aaron Iba, Jessica Livingston, Robert Morris, Harj Taggar, and Garry Tan for reading drafts of this.

感谢 Sam Altman、Patrick Collison、Aaron Iba、Jessica Livingston、Robert Morris、Harj Taggar 和 Garry Tan 阅读本文初稿。

entry.title: 厌恶性盲区
entry.content:
Schlep Blindness

原文链接: https://paulgraham.com/schlep.html

January 2012

There are great startup ideas lying around unexploited right under our noses. One reason we don’t see them is a phenomenon I call schlep blindness. Schlep was originally a Yiddish word but has passed into general use in the US. It means a tedious, unpleasant task.
我们身边其实到处都是尚未被发掘的绝佳创业点子。我们之所以看不到它们，原因之一就是我称之为“schlep盲视”的现象。“Schlep”原本是一个意第绪语词汇，但已在美国通用，意指枯燥、令人不快的任务。

No one likes schleps, but hackers especially dislike them. Most hackers who start startups wish they could do it by just writing some clever software, putting it on a server somewhere, and watching the money roll in—without ever having to talk to users, or negotiate with other companies, or deal with other people’s broken code. Maybe that’s possible, but I haven’t seen it.
没人喜欢schlep，而程序员（黑客）尤其讨厌它们。大多数创办初创公司的程序员都希望只需写出一些巧妙的软件，把它部署到某个服务器上，然后坐等金钱滚滚而来——完全不必与用户沟通、与其他公司谈判，或处理别人写得一团糟的代码。也许这在理论上可行，但我从未见过这样的例子。

One of the many things we do at Y Combinator is teach hackers about the inevitability of schleps. No, you can’t start a startup by just writing code. I remember going through this realization myself. There was a point in 1995 when I was still trying to convince myself I could start a company by just writing code. But I soon learned from experience that schleps are not merely inevitable, but pretty much what business consists of. A company is defined by the schleps it will undertake. And schleps should be dealt with the same way you’d deal with a cold swimming pool: just jump in. Which is not to say you should seek out unpleasant work per se, but that you should never shrink from it if it’s on the path to something great.
我们在Y Combinator所做的一件事，就是教导程序员们认识到schlep是不可避免的。不，你不可能仅靠写代码就创办一家公司。我记得自己也曾经历过这一认知转变。1995年时，我还在试图说服自己：只要写好代码就能开公司。但很快我就从经验中学到，schlep不仅不可避免，而且几乎构成了商业的全部内容。一家公司的本质，正是由它愿意承担哪些schlep所定义的。面对schlep，你应该像面对冰冷的游泳池一样：直接跳进去。这并不是说你应该刻意追求令人不快的工作，而是说，如果某项艰苦工作通向伟大的目标，你就绝不应退缩。

The most dangerous thing about our dislike of schleps is that much of it is unconscious. Your unconscious won’t even let you see ideas that involve painful schleps. That’s schlep blindness.
我们对schlep的厌恶最危险之处在于，这种厌恶很大程度上是无意识的。你的潜意识甚至会阻止你看到那些涉及痛苦schlep的创意。这就是“schlep盲视”。

The phenomenon isn’t limited to startups. Most people don’t consciously decide not to be in as good physical shape as Olympic athletes, for example. Their unconscious mind decides for them, shrinking from the work involved.
这种现象并不仅限于创业领域。例如，大多数人并非有意识地决定不去练就奥运选手般的体魄；而是他们的潜意识替他们做了决定，因为畏惧其中所需的艰苦训练。

The most striking example I know of schlep blindness is Stripe, or rather Stripe’s idea. For over a decade, every hacker who’d ever had to process payments online knew how painful the experience was. Thousands of people must have known about this problem. And yet when they started startups, they decided to build recipe sites, or aggregators for local events. Why? Why work on problems few care much about and no one will pay for, when you could fix one of the most important components of the world’s infrastructure? Because schlep blindness prevented people from even considering the idea of fixing payments.
我所知道的“schlep盲视”最典型的例子就是Stripe，更准确地说，是Stripe背后的想法。十多年来，每个曾在线处理过支付的程序员都知道这个过程有多痛苦。成千上万的人都清楚这个问题的存在。然而当他们开始创业时，却选择去做菜谱网站或本地活动聚合平台。为什么？明明你可以去修复全球基础设施中最关键的环节之一，却偏偏要解决几乎没人关心、也没人愿意付费的问题？原因就在于“schlep盲视”让人们根本不会考虑去解决支付问题。

Probably no one who applied to Y Combinator to work on a recipe site began by asking “should we fix payments, or build a recipe site?” and chose the recipe site. Though the idea of fixing payments was right there in plain sight, they never saw it, because their unconscious mind shrank from the complications involved. You’d have to make deals with banks. How do you do that? Plus you’re moving money, so you’re going to have to deal with fraud, and people trying to break into your servers. Plus there are probably all sorts of regulations to comply with. It’s a lot more intimidating to start a startup like this than a recipe site.
可能没有哪个申请Y Combinator、打算做菜谱网站的人，是从“我们应该解决支付问题，还是做个菜谱网站？”这个问题出发，然后主动选择了后者。尽管解决支付问题的想法就在眼前，但他们根本看不见，因为他们的潜意识本能地回避其中的复杂性：你得和银行谈合作——这怎么做？而且你是在处理资金流动，所以必须应对欺诈行为，以及试图攻破你服务器的人。此外，很可能还要遵守各种各样的法规。相比做一个菜谱网站，创办这样一家公司要吓人得多。

That scariness makes ambitious ideas doubly valuable. In addition to their intrinsic value, they’re like undervalued stocks in the sense that there’s less demand for them among founders. If you pick an ambitious idea, you’ll have less competition, because everyone else will have been frightened off by the challenges involved. (This is also true of starting a startup generally.)
正因如此，雄心勃勃的创意具有双重价值。除了其内在价值外，它们就像被低估的股票——因为创业者们对这类想法的需求更少。如果你选择一个雄心勃勃的创意，你将面临更少的竞争，因为其他人都被其中的挑战吓退了。（这一点在创业领域普遍适用。）

How do you overcome schlep blindness? Frankly, the most valuable antidote to schlep blindness is probably ignorance. Most successful founders would probably say that if they’d known when they were starting their company about the obstacles they’d have to overcome, they might never have started it. Maybe that’s one reason the most successful startups of all so often have young founders.
那么，如何克服“schlep盲视”呢？坦白说，对抗“schlep盲视”最有效的解药或许是无知。大多数成功的创始人可能会说，如果他们在创业之初就知道未来要克服哪些障碍，或许根本就不会开始。这也许就是为什么最成功的初创公司往往由年轻人创办的原因之一。

In practice the founders grow with the problems. But no one seems able to foresee that, not even older, more experienced founders. So the reason younger founders have an advantage is that they make two mistakes that cancel each other out. They don’t know how much they can grow, but they also don’t know how much they’ll need to. Older founders only make the first mistake.
实际上，创始人会随着问题一起成长。但似乎没人能预见到这一点，即便是年长、更有经验的创始人也做不到。因此，年轻创始人之所以有优势，是因为他们犯了两个相互抵消的错误：他们不知道自己能成长多少，但也同样不知道自己需要成长多少。而年长的创始人只犯了第一个错误。

Ignorance can’t solve everything though. Some ideas so obviously entail alarming schleps that anyone can see them. How do you see ideas like that? The trick I recommend is to take yourself out of the picture. Instead of asking “what problem should I solve?” ask “what problem do I wish someone else would solve for me?” If someone who had to process payments before Stripe had tried asking that, Stripe would have been one of the first things they wished for.
不过，无知并不能解决所有问题。有些创意显然包含令人望而生畏的schlep，任何人都看得出来。那么，该如何发现这类创意呢？我推荐的技巧是把自己抽离出来。不要问“我应该解决什么问题？”，而是问“我希望别人为我解决什么问题？”如果在Stripe出现之前，某个需要处理在线支付的人曾这样自问，Stripe很可能就是他最先希望有人解决的问题之一。

It’s too late now to be Stripe, but there’s plenty still broken in the world, if you know how to see it.
现在再想成为Stripe已经太迟了，但世界上仍有许多亟待修复的问题——只要你懂得如何看见它们。

Thanks to Sam Altman, Paul Buchheit, Patrick Collison, Aaron Iba, Jessica Livingston, Emmett Shear, and Harj Taggar for reading drafts of this.
感谢Sam Altman、Paul Buchheit、Patrick Collison、Aaron Iba、Jessica Livingston、Emmett Shear和Harj Taggar阅读本文草稿

entry.title: 创业中心为何能成功
entry.content:
Why Startup Hubs Work

创业中心为何能成功

原文链接: https://paulgraham.com/hubs.html

October 2011

If you look at a list of US cities sorted by population, the number of successful startups per capita varies by orders of magnitude. Somehow it’s as if most places were sprayed with startupicide.若查看美国按人口排序的城市名单，会发现各城市人均成功创业公司数量相差极大。不知为何，多数地区仿佛被喷洒了 “创业杀手”（注：作者造词，指抑制创业的因素）。

I wondered about this for years. I could see the average town was like a roach motel for startup ambitions: smart, ambitious people went in, but no startups came out. But I was never able to figure out exactly what happened inside the motel—exactly what was killing all the potential startups. [1]多年来我一直对此感到困惑。我发现普通城镇就像 “蟑螂旅馆”（注：比喻只进不出的地方），吞噬着创业抱负：聪明且有野心的人踏入其中，却没有创业公司能从中诞生。但我始终无法弄清楚 “旅馆” 内部究竟发生了什么 —— 究竟是什么扼杀了所有潜在的创业公司。[1]

A couple weeks ago I finally figured it out. I was framing the question wrong. The problem is not that most towns kill startups. It’s that death is the default for startups, and most towns don’t save them. Instead of thinking of most places as being sprayed with startupicide, it’s more accurate to think of startups as all being poisoned, and a few places being sprayed with the antidote.几周前我终于找到了答案。此前我一直用错了思考框架。问题不在于多数城镇会扼杀创业公司，而在于 “失败” 本就是创业公司的默认结局，且多数城镇无法挽救它们。与其认为多数地区被喷洒了 “创业杀手”，不如将所有创业公司视为 “中毒者”，而少数地区则被喷洒了 “解药”，这种说法更为准确。

Startups in other places are just doing what startups naturally do: fail. The real question is, what’s saving startups in places like Silicon Valley? [2]其他地区的创业公司只是在做创业公司本能会做的事：失败。真正的问题是，像硅谷这样的地方，究竟是什么在挽救创业公司？[2]

Environment

环境因素

I think there are two components to the antidote: being in a place where startups are the cool thing to do, and chance meetings with people who can help you. And what drives them both is the number of startup people around you.我认为 “解药” 包含两个要素：一是身处一个 “创业是件很酷的事” 的环境，二是能偶然遇到可提供帮助的人。而驱动这两个要素的关键，在于你身边 “创业相关人士” 的数量。

The first component is particularly helpful in the first stage of a startup’s life, when you go from merely having an interest in starting a company to actually doing it. It’s quite a leap to start a startup. It’s an unusual thing to do. But in Silicon Valley it seems normal. [3]第一个要素在创业公司的初始阶段尤为重要，也就是当你从 “只是有创业兴趣” 转变为 “真正付诸行动” 的阶段。创办一家创业公司是巨大的跨越，并非寻常之举，但在硅谷，这似乎是件很正常的事。[3]

In most places, if you start a startup, people treat you as if you’re unemployed. People in the Valley aren’t automatically impressed with you just because you’re starting a company, but they pay attention. Anyone who’s been here any amount of time knows not to default to skepticism, no matter how inexperienced you seem or how unpromising your idea sounds at first, because they’ve all seen inexperienced founders with unpromising sounding ideas who a few years later were billionaires.在多数地区，若你创办创业公司，人们会把你当成失业者。硅谷的人不会仅仅因为你在创业就对你另眼相看，但他们会关注你。任何在硅谷待过一段时间的人都知道，不应默认持怀疑态度 —— 无论你看起来多缺乏经验，无论你的想法起初听起来多没前景。因为他们都见过这样的案例：曾经缺乏经验、想法看似无望的创始人，几年后却成了亿万富翁。

Having people around you care about what you’re doing is an extraordinarily powerful force. Even the most willful people are susceptible to it. About a year after we started Y Combinator I said something to a partner at a well known VC firm that gave him the (mistaken) impression I was considering starting another startup. He responded so eagerly that for about half a second I found myself considering doing it.身边有人关注你所做的事，这是一种极具力量的推动力，即便最固执的人也会受其影响。在我们创办 Y Combinator（注：知名创业孵化器）约一年后，我曾和一家知名风投公司的合伙人聊起某事，让他产生了一个（错误的）印象：我在考虑再创办一家创业公司。他的反应极为热切，以至于那一瞬间我真的开始认真考虑这件事。

In most other cities, the prospect of starting a startup just doesn’t seem real. In the Valley it’s not only real but fashionable. That no doubt causes a lot of people to start startups who shouldn’t. But I think that’s ok. Few people are suited to running a startup, and it’s very hard to predict beforehand which are (as I know all too well from being in the business of trying to predict beforehand), so lots of people starting startups who shouldn’t is probably the optimal state of affairs. As long as you’re at a point in your life when you can bear the risk of failure, the best way to find out if you’re suited to running a startup is to try it.在其他多数城市，“创办创业公司” 这件事看起来就不真实。但在硅谷，它不仅真实，还很时髦。这无疑会让很多本不适合创业的人也投身其中，但我认为这并无不妥。适合经营创业公司的人本就不多，且提前预测谁适合更是难上加难（我身处这一行，对此深有体会）。因此，让很多本不适合的人尝试创业，或许是最佳状态。只要你正处于人生中能承担失败风险的阶段，想知道自己是否适合经营创业公司，最好的方法就是去尝试。

Chance

偶然因素

The second component of the antidote is chance meetings with people who can help you. This force works in both phases: both in the transition from the desire to start a startup to starting one, and the transition from starting a company to succeeding. The power of chance meetings is more variable than people around you caring about startups, which is like a sort of background radiation that affects everyone equally, but at its strongest it is far stronger.“解药” 的第二个要素是 “偶然遇到能提供帮助的人”。这种力量在两个阶段都发挥作用：一是从 “有创业意愿” 到 “实际创业” 的过渡阶段，二是从 “创办公司” 到 “取得成功” 的过渡阶段。相较于 “身边人关注创业” 这种像 “背景辐射” 一样平等影响所有人的力量，偶然相遇的影响力更具不确定性，但在其最强时，威力要大得多。

Chance meetings produce miracles to compensate for the disasters that characteristically befall startups. In the Valley, terrible things happen to startups all the time, just like they do to startups everywhere. The reason startups are more likely to make it here is that great things happen to them too. In the Valley, lightning has a sign bit.偶然相遇能创造奇迹，弥补创业公司常遭遇的灾难。在硅谷，创业公司总会遇到糟糕的事，这和其他地方的创业公司并无二致。但硅谷的创业公司更有可能成功，原因在于它们也会遇到好事。可以说，在硅谷，“好运” 是带有 “标识” 的（注：比喻好运更易降临）。

For example, you start a site for college students and you decide to move to the Valley for the summer to work on it. And then on a random suburban street in Palo Alto you happen to run into Sean Parker, who understands the domain really well because he started a similar startup himself, and also knows all the investors. And moreover has advanced views, for 2004, on founders retaining control of their companies.举个例子：你创办了一个面向大学生的网站，并决定夏天搬到硅谷专注运营它。然后在帕洛阿尔托（注：硅谷核心城市之一）一条普通的郊区街道上，你偶然遇到了肖恩・帕克（注：Napster 和 Facebook 早期高管，创业领域资深人士）。他对这个领域了如指掌 —— 因为他自己就创办过类似的创业公司，还认识所有投资人。此外，在 2004 年那个年代，他就对 “创始人保留公司控制权” 有着超前的见解。

You can’t say precisely what the miracle will be, or even for sure that one will happen. The best one can say is: if you’re in a startup hub, unexpected good things will probably happen to you, especially if you deserve them.你无法准确预测会遇到什么样的奇迹，甚至无法确定奇迹是否会发生。但可以肯定的是：若你身处创业中心，意外的好事很可能会降临到你身上，尤其是当你配得上这些好事时。

I bet this is true even for startups we fund. Even with us working to make things happen for them on purpose rather than by accident, the frequency of helpful chance meetings in the Valley is so high that it’s still a significant increment on what we can deliver.我敢说，即便是我们投资的创业公司，情况也是如此。即便我们刻意为它们创造机会，而非依赖偶然，硅谷中 “有帮助的偶然相遇” 频率依然极高，这仍是我们所能提供资源之外的重要补充。

Chance meetings play a role like the role relaxation plays in having ideas. Most people have had the experience of working hard on some problem, not being able to solve it, giving up and going to bed, and then thinking of the answer in the shower in the morning. What makes the answer appear is letting your thoughts drift a bit—and thus drift off the wrong path you’d been pursuing last night and onto the right one adjacent to it.偶然相遇的作用，就像 “放松” 在 “产生灵感” 过程中所起的作用。多数人都有过这样的经历：努力解决某个问题却无果，只好放弃去睡觉，第二天早上洗澡时却突然想到了答案。答案之所以会出现，是因为你让思绪稍微 “飘移” 了 —— 从昨晚执着的错误路径上移开，飘到了旁边正确的路径上。

Chance meetings let your acquaintance drift in the same way taking a shower lets your thoughts drift. The critical thing in both cases is that they drift just the right amount. The meeting between Larry Page and Sergey Brin was a good example. They let their acquaintance drift, but only a little; they were both meeting someone they had a lot in common with.偶然相遇能让你的 “人脉圈” 发生飘移，就像洗澡能让你的思绪飘移一样。两种情况的关键在于，“飘移” 的程度恰到好处。拉里・佩奇（注：谷歌联合创始人）和谢尔盖・布林（注：谷歌联合创始人）的相遇就是个好例子。他们的人脉圈发生了飘移，但幅度不大 —— 他们遇到的是与自己有很多共同点的人。

For Larry Page the most important component of the antidote was Sergey Brin, and vice versa. The antidote is people. It’s not the physical infrastructure of Silicon Valley that makes it work, or the weather, or anything like that. Those helped get it started, but now that the reaction is self-sustaining what drives it is the people.对拉里・佩奇而言，“解药” 中最重要的要素是谢尔盖・布林，反之亦然。“解药” 的核心是人。让硅谷成功的，不是它的实体基础设施，也不是天气或其他类似因素。这些因素确实帮助硅谷起步，但如今其发展已形成自我循环，驱动这一切的核心是人。

Many observers have noticed that one of the most distinctive things about startup hubs is the degree to which people help one another out, with no expectation of getting anything in return. I’m not sure why this is so. Perhaps it’s because startups are less of a zero sum game than most types of business; they are rarely killed by competitors. Or perhaps it’s because so many startup founders have backgrounds in the sciences, where collaboration is encouraged.许多观察人士注意到，创业中心最显著的特征之一，是人们会主动互相帮助，且不期望任何回报。我不确定背后的原因是什么。或许是因为创业公司不像多数行业那样属于 “零和博弈”（注：一方获利必然导致另一方损失），它们很少被竞争对手击垮；又或许是因为很多创业公司创始人拥有科学领域背景，而该领域本身就鼓励合作。

A large part of YC’s function is to accelerate that process. We’re a sort of Valley within the Valley, where the density of people working on startups and their willingness to help one another are both artificially amplified.Y Combinator 的很大一部分职能就是加速这一过程。我们就像是 “硅谷中的硅谷”—— 在这里，创业相关人士的密度以及他们互相帮助的意愿，都被人为地放大了。

Numbers

人数因素

Both components of the antidote—an environment that encourages startups, and chance meetings with people who help you—are driven by the same underlying cause: the number of startup people around you. To make a startup hub, you need a lot of people interested in startups.“解药” 的两个要素 —— 鼓励创业的环境、偶然遇到能提供帮助的人 —— 都源于同一个根本原因：你身边 “创业相关人士” 的数量。要打造一个创业中心，就需要大量对创业感兴趣的人。

There are three reasons. The first, obviously, is that if you don’t have enough density, the chance meetings don’t happen. [4] The second is that different startups need such different things, so you need a lot of people to supply each startup with what they need most. Sean Parker was exactly what Facebook needed in 2004. Another startup might have needed a database guy, or someone with connections in the movie business.原因有三点。第一，很明显，若相关人士密度不够，就不会有那么多偶然相遇的机会。[4] 第二，不同的创业公司需求差异极大，因此需要足够多的人，才能为每家公司提供其最急需的资源。肖恩・帕克正是 2004 年 Facebook 所需要的人，而另一家创业公司可能需要的是数据库专家，或是在电影行业有人脉的人。

This is one of the reasons we fund such a large number of companies, incidentally. The bigger the community, the greater the chance it will contain the person who has that one thing you need most.顺便说一句，这也是我们投资大量公司的原因之一。社群规模越大，其中包含 “能提供你最急需资源的人” 的概率就越高。

The third reason you need a lot of people to make a startup hub is that once you have enough people interested in the same problem, they start to set the social norms. And it is a particularly valuable thing when the atmosphere around you encourages you to do something that would otherwise seem too ambitious. In most places the atmosphere pulls you back toward the mean.需要大量人群才能打造创业中心的第三个原因是：一旦有足够多的人对同一问题（注：指创业）感兴趣，他们就会开始建立社会规范。当周围的氛围鼓励你去做那些原本看似 “过于雄心勃勃” 的事时，这种规范的价值就会凸显。而在多数地区，氛围只会把你拉向 “平庸”。

I flew into the Bay Area a few days ago. I notice this every time I fly over the Valley: somehow you can sense something is going on. Obviously you can sense prosperity in how well kept a place looks. But there are different kinds of prosperity. Silicon Valley doesn’t look like Boston, or New York, or LA, or DC. I tried asking myself what word I’d use to describe the feeling the Valley radiated, and the word that came to mind was optimism.几天前我飞往旧金山湾区（注：硅谷所在区域）。每次飞越硅谷时我都会注意到：你能隐约感觉到这里正在发生一些特别的事。显然，从一个地方的整洁程度能看出其繁荣，但繁荣有不同的类型。硅谷看起来不像波士顿、纽约、洛杉矶或华盛顿特区。我试着问自己，该用哪个词来描述硅谷所散发的氛围，脑海中浮现的词是 “乐观”。

Notes

注释

[1] I’m not saying it’s impossible to succeed in a city with few other startups, just harder. If you’re sufficiently good at generating your own morale, you can survive without external encouragement. Wufoo was based in Tampa and they succeeded. But the Wufoos are exceptionally disciplined.[1] 我并非说在其他创业公司寥寥无几的城市就无法成功，只是难度会更大。如果你足够擅长自我激励，即便没有外部鼓励也能坚持下去。Wufoo（注：知名表单工具公司）的总部位于坦帕，且取得了成功，但 Wufoo 团队拥有极其出色的自律性。

[2] Incidentally, this phenomenon is not limited to startups. Most unusual ambitions fail, unless the person who has them manages to find the right sort of community.[2] 顺便提一句，这种现象并非只存在于创业领域。多数不寻常的远大目标都会以失败告终，除非拥有这些目标的人能找到合适的社群支持。

[3] Starting a company is common, but starting a startup is rare. I’ve talked about the distinction between the two elsewhere, but essentially a startup is a new business designed for scale. Most new businesses are service businesses and except in rare cases those don’t scale.[3] 创办公司很常见，但创办 “创业公司”（startup）却很罕见。我曾在其他地方讨论过二者的区别，本质上，创业公司是一种 “为规模化发展而设计的新业务”。多数新公司都属于服务型企业，除极少数情况外，这类企业难以实现规模化扩张。

[4] As I was writing this, I had a demonstration of the density of startup people in the Valley. Jessica and I bicycled to University Ave in Palo Alto to have lunch at the fabulous Oren’s Hummus. As we walked in, we met Charlie Cheever sitting near the door. Selina Tobaccowala stopped to say hello on her way out. Then Josh Wilson came in to pick up a take out order. After lunch we went to get frozen yogurt. On the way we met Rajat Suri. When we got to the yogurt place, we found Dave Shen there, and as we walked out we ran into Yuri Sagalov. We walked with him for a block or so and we ran into Muzzammil Zaveri, and then a block later we met Aydin Senkut. This is everyday life in Palo Alto. I wasn’t trying to meet people; I was just having lunch. And I’m sure for every startup founder or investor I saw that I knew, there were 5 more I didn’t. If Ron Conway had been with us he would have met 30 people he knew.[4] 在我撰写本文时，恰好有一件事能体现硅谷创业相关人士的密度。我和杰西卡骑自行车到帕洛阿尔托的大学大道，去很棒的 Oren’s Hummus 餐厅吃午饭。进门时，我们看到查理・奇弗（注：知名创业者，曾联合创办 Quora）坐在门边；塞莉娜・托巴科瓦拉（注：科技行业高管、创业者）出门时特意停下来打招呼；之后乔希・威尔逊（注：创业领域人士）进来取外卖。午饭后我们去买冻酸奶，路上遇到了拉贾特・苏里（注：创业者）；到了酸奶店，又碰到戴夫・沈（注：创业领域人士）；出门时撞见了尤里・萨加洛夫（注：创业者）。我们和他一起走了一个街区左右，遇到了穆扎米尔・扎韦里（注：创业领域人士）；再走一个街区，又碰到了艾丁・森库特（注：风投家）。这就是帕洛阿尔托的日常生活 —— 我并没有刻意去见人，只是去吃了个午饭。而且我敢肯定，我遇到的每一个认识的创业公司创始人或投资人背后，还有 5 个我不认识的同行。如果罗恩・康威（注：硅谷知名天使投资人，人脉极广）和我们在一起，他大概能遇到 30 个认识的人。

Thanks to Sam Altman, Paul Buchheit, Jessica Livingston, and Harj Taggar for reading drafts of this.感谢萨姆・奥尔特曼、保罗・布赫海特、杰西卡・利文斯顿和哈杰・塔格尔阅读本文初稿并提出意见。（注：四人均为硅谷科技界或投资界资深人士，其中萨姆・奥尔特曼曾任 Y Combinator 总裁，保罗・布赫海特是 Gmail 创始人）

entry.title: 专利承诺
entry.content:
The Patent Pledge

专利承诺

原文链接: https://paulgraham.com/patentpledge.html

August 2011

I realized recently that we may be able to solve part of the patent problem without waiting for the government.我最近意识到，无需等待政府介入，我们或许就能解决部分专利问题。

I’ve never been 100% sure whether patents help or hinder technological progress. When I was a kid I thought they helped. I thought they protected inventors from having their ideas stolen by big companies. Maybe that was truer in the past, when more things were physical. But regardless of whether patents are in general a good thing, there do seem to be bad ways of using them. And since bad uses of patents seem to be increasing, there is an increasing call for patent reform.我始终无法 100% 确定，专利究竟是在推动还是阻碍技术进步。小时候我认为专利是有益的，它能保护发明者的想法不被大公司窃取。在过去，当更多产品还属于实体范畴时，这种说法可能更成立。但无论专利总体上是否有益，其使用方式中确实存在不当之处。而且，随着专利滥用现象愈发频繁，要求专利改革的呼声也日益高涨。

The problem with patent reform is that it has to go through the government. That tends to be slow. But recently I realized we can also attack the problem downstream. As well as pinching off the stream of patents at the point where they’re issued, we may in some cases be able to pinch it off at the point where they’re used.专利改革的问题在于，它必须通过政府推进，而这个过程往往十分缓慢。但最近我意识到，我们还可以从下游入手解决问题。除了在专利授权环节遏制不当专利的产生，在某些情况下，我们还能在专利使用环节切断其滥用的可能。

One way of using patents that clearly does not encourage innovation is when established companies with bad products use patents to suppress small competitors with good products. This is the type of abuse we may be able to decrease without having to go through the government.有一种专利使用方式显然无法推动创新：产品欠佳的老牌公司利用专利打压产品更优的小型竞争对手。这类滥用行为，或许无需政府介入，我们就能减少其发生。

The way to do it is to get the companies that are above pulling this sort of trick to pledge publicly not to. Then the ones that won’t make such a pledge will be very conspicuous. Potential employees won’t want to work for them. And investors, too, will be able to see that they’re the sort of company that competes by litigation rather than by making good products.解决之道是让那些不屑于使用此类手段的公司公开承诺不这么做。如此一来，不愿做出该承诺的公司便会格外显眼。潜在员工将不愿为其工作，投资者也能看清，这类公司选择通过诉讼而非打造优质产品来竞争。

Here’s the pledge:以下是具体承诺内容：

No first use of software patents against companies with less than 25 people.不首先对员工人数少于 25 人的公司动用软件专利。

I’ve deliberately traded precision for brevity. The patent pledge is not legally binding. It’s like Google’s “Don’t be evil.” They don’t define what evil is, but by publicly saying that, they’re saying they’re willing to be held to a standard that, say, Altria is not. And though constraining, “Don’t be evil” has been good for Google. Technology companies win by attracting the most productive people, and the most productive people are attracted to employers who hold themselves to a higher standard than the law requires. [1]我特意牺牲了精确性以追求简洁。该专利承诺不具备法律约束力，类似谷歌的 “不作恶” 原则。谷歌并未定义 “恶” 的具体含义，但通过公开这一原则，他们表明自己愿意遵守一个更高的标准 —— 比如奥驰亚集团（Altria）就不会这样做。尽管 “不作恶” 带有约束性，但它对谷歌而言是有益的。科技公司的成功在于吸引最高效的人才，而最高效的人才更倾向于选择那些自我要求高于法律规定的雇主。[1]

The patent pledge is in effect a narrower but open source “Don’t be evil.” I encourage every technology company to adopt it. If you want to help fix patents, encourage your employer to.实质上，这项专利承诺是范围更窄但具有开源性质的 “不作恶” 原则。我鼓励所有科技公司采纳它。如果你想为解决专利问题出一份力，就去劝说你的雇主加入。

Already most technology companies wouldn’t sink to using patents on startups. You don’t see Google or Facebook suing startups for patent infringement. They don’t need to. So for the better technology companies, the patent pledge requires no change in behavior. They’re just promising to do what they’d do anyway. And when all the companies that won’t use patents on startups have said so, the holdouts will be very conspicuous.如今，大多数科技公司本就不屑于对初创公司动用专利。你不会看到谷歌或脸书（Facebook）以专利侵权为由起诉初创公司，他们也无需这样做。因此，对于优秀的科技公司而言，遵守专利承诺无需改变现有行为，他们只是在承诺会继续做自己原本就会做的事。而当所有不愿对初创公司动用专利的公司都公开表态后，那些拒不承诺的公司便会格外扎眼。

The patent pledge doesn’t fix every problem with patents. It won’t stop patent trolls, for example; they’re already pariahs. But the problem the patent pledge does fix may be more serious than the problem of patent trolls. Patent trolls are just parasites. A clumsy parasite may occasionally kill the host, but that’s not its goal. Whereas companies that sue startups for patent infringement generally do it with explicit goal of keeping their product off the market.这项专利承诺无法解决所有专利问题。例如，它无法阻止 “专利流氓”（专门以诉讼为生的专利持有者）—— 这类群体本就已是众矢之的。但该承诺所解决的问题，可能比 “专利流氓” 问题更为严重。“专利流氓” 不过是寄生虫，即便笨拙的寄生虫偶尔会杀死宿主，这也并非其本意。而那些以专利侵权为由起诉初创公司的企业，其目的往往很明确：阻止初创公司的产品进入市场。

Companies that use patents on startups are attacking innovation at the root. Now there’s something any individual can do about this problem, without waiting for the government: ask companies where they stand.对初创公司动用专利的企业，是在从根源上打击创新。如今，无需等待政府行动，每个人都能为此出一份力：去询问各个公司对此事的立场。

Notes:

注释：

[1] Because the pledge is deliberately vague, we’re going to need common sense when intepreting it. And even more vice versa: the pledge is vague in order to make people use common sense when interpreting it.[1] 由于该承诺特意保留了模糊性，我们在解读时需凭借常识判断。反之亦然，承诺的模糊性恰恰是为了让人们在解读时运用常识。

So for example I’ve deliberately avoided saying whether the 25 people have to be employees, or whether contractors count too. If a company has to split hairs that fine about whether a suit would violate the patent pledge, it’s probably still a dick move.例如，我特意没有明确规定这 25 人必须是正式员工，还是也包括外包人员。如果一家公司需要在 “某次诉讼是否违反专利承诺” 这类问题上吹毛求疵，那它的行为很可能依然是不光彩的。

entry.title: 创始人控制权
entry.content:
Founder Control

创始人控制权

原文链接: https://paulgraham.com/control.html

December 2010

Someone we funded is talking to VCs now, and asked me how common it was for a startup’s founders to retain control of the board after a series A round. He said VCs told him this almost never happened.我们投资过的一家公司正在与风投接触，创始人问我，初创公司在 A 轮融资后，创始人保留董事会控制权的情况有多普遍。他表示，风投告诉他这种情况几乎不可能发生。

Ten years ago that was true. In the past, founders rarely kept control of the board through a series A. The traditional series A board consisted of two founders, two VCs, and one independent member. More recently the recipe is often one founder, one VC, and one independent. In either case the founders lose their majority.十年前，情况确实如此。过去，创始人很少能在 A 轮融资后仍掌握董事会控制权。传统的 A 轮董事会结构通常是 2 名创始人、2 名风投代表和 1 名独立董事。近年来，常见的结构变成了 1 名创始人、1 名风投代表和 1 名独立董事。无论哪种结构，创始人都失去了多数席位。

But not always. Mark Zuckerberg kept control of Facebook’s board through the series A and still has it today. Mark Pincus has kept control of Zynga’s too. But are these just outliers? How common is it for founders to keep control after an A round?
